properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard or near blizzard conditions improving at Clyde River tonight. An intense low pressure system over southern Davis Strait is causing strong northwest winds of 50 gusting 70 km/h at Clyde River. Similar conditions will persist into the early evening hours with poor visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions will start to improve during the night as winds slowly diminish. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T07:24:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T20:52:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2654031355.2020
Area: Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions continue. Although there may be intermittent improvement tonight, poor visibility will persist until Friday morning with wind gusts near 80 km/h. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds expected beginning Friday. Total snowfall: 15 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 100 km/h or higher beginning Saturday. Locations: along the mid and north Labrador Coast. Time span: Friday afternoon through Sunday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to spread across Labrador on Friday. On Saturday, strong northwesterly winds are expected to combine with fresh snow along the Labrador Coast to bring poor visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions will improve by Sunday morning. The public is advised to monitor future forecasts as winter weather warnings may be required for the mid and north Labrador coast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-20T17:34:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-20T01:35:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1432230224.2020
Area: Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity, Nain and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant Rain, Thunderstorms, and Potential Briefly Severe Wind Gusts on the way. An approaching warm front will cause an area of showers and thunderstorms to move through the regions this evening. Some of the storms will contain heavy downpours with local rainfall amounts of 25 mm in an hour possible. A few showers or thunderstorms are also expected overnight in some areas. There is the risk that isolated thunderstorms overnight could contain wind gusts to 90 km/h. A greater threat for high wind gusts is expected Friday morning into early afternoon as a cold front approaches, preceded by a band of scattered showers and thunderstorms. There will be potential for wind gusts near or in excess of 90 km/h as the band moves through. Should these winds develop, power outages would likely occur in some areas. Environment Canada will continue to monitor this situation closely and may issue watches or warnings as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T12:38:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T20:39:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2766695603.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and strong wind gusts on the way. A warm front will cause an area of showers and thunderstorms to move through the area early tonight. Some of the storms will contain heavy downpours with local rainfall amounts up to 25 mm possible. A few showers or thunderstorms are also expected overnight in some areas. Then during the day Friday, strong northwesterly winds are forecast to develop during the afternoon in the wake of a strong cold front. Wind gusts up to 70 or 80 km/h can be expected in some areas. Environment Canada will continue to monitor this situation closely. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR BURNS LAKE, SMITHERS, QUESNEL AND VERNON The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory for Burns Lake and Smithers because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-20T17:38:17-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain, thunderstorms, and brief strong wind gusts on the way. Showers and scattered thunderstorms tonight into Friday with up to 25 mm possible in some areas. A warm front will cause an area of showers and thunderstorms to move across the area early tonight. Some of the storms may contain heavy downpours with local amounts in the 15 to 25 mm range possible. There will be the potential for high wind gusts Friday in the morning or early afternoon as a cold front approaches, preceded by a band of scattered showers and thunderstorms. Scattered wind gusts near or exceeding 90 km/h or more will be possible in this band. Given the scattered nature of the band, confidence in high winds gusts occurring in any given place is low. Where these winds develop, power outages would likely occur. Environment Canada will continue to monitor this situation closely and may issue watches or warnings as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T17:41:27-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain tonight changing to snow overnight or on Friday. Rain, heavy at times, will begin this evening with amounts in the 15 to 25 mm range possible. There will be a transition to snow overnight or on Friday morning. The snow will taper off by Friday evening, with total snowfall amounts up to 10 cm expected by the time the snow comes to an end. On Friday morning, a cold front will sweep from west to east with a fairly dramatic temperature drop through the afternoon. This may result in icy conditions on untreated surfaces. Gusty winds up to 60 kilometres per hour may also result in isolated power outages on Friday. If visibility is reduced while driving, turn on your lights and maintain a safe following distance. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T13:30:25-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall, followed by significant rainfall is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total snowfall: generally between 5 and 10 cm. Total rainfall: generally 25 to 50 mm with locally 60 mm along the south coast. Locations: southern and western Newfoundland. Time span: Friday morning through Saturday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin early Friday and quickly change to rain at times heavy by late Friday. Conditions will improve by Saturday morning. Strong southerly winds and mild air temperatures will accompany the rainfall to cause significant snowmelt and runoff leading to potential flooding. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-20T17:33:52-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Potential for Brief Severe Wind Gusts Friday Morning or Early Afternoon. Showers and Scattered Thunderstorms Tonight into Friday with up to 25 mm Possible in Some Areas. An approaching warm front will cause an area of showers and thunderstorms to move through the regions later this evening and tonight. Some of the storms may contain heavy downpours with local rainfall amounts of 15 mm in an hour or total amounts near 25 mm possible. There will be the potential for high wind gusts Friday in the morning or early afternoon as a cold front approaches, preceded by a band of scattered showers and thunderstorms. Scattered wind gusts near or exceeding 90 km/h or more will be possible in this band. Given the scattered nature of the band, confidence in high winds gusts occurring in any given place is low. Where these winds develop, power outages would likely occur. Environment Canada will continue to monitor this situation closely and may issue watches or warnings as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential Brief Severe Wind Gusts Friday. A strong cold front will sweep across the regions late Friday morning and Friday afternoon. A band of scattered showers or thunderstorms is expected to develop just ahead of the front. The band will affect areas near Lake Simcoe in the late morning or around noon, then move rapidly eastward to reach eastern Ontario in the mid afternoon. Winds gusts near or in excess of 90 km/h will be possible in some areas as the band moves through. Given that the showers and thunderstorms are expected to be scattered, strong wind gusts will only affect some areas with low confidence as to the locales most likely to be affected. Power outages are expected where high wind gusts occur. Environment Canada will continue to monitor this situation closely. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T12:36:55-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and strong wind gusts on the way. A warm front will cause an area of showers and thunderstorms to move through the area early tonight. Some of the storms will contain heavy downpours with local rainfall amounts up to 25 mm possible. A few showers or thunderstorms are also expected overnight in some areas. In the wake of the warm front Friday morning, strong southwesterly winds are forecast to develop over the lower Great Lakes. Wind gusts up to 90 km/h are expected Friday morning into early Friday afternoon. Then Friday afternoon a cold front will move across the area from west to east. This cold front will be preceded by a band of scattered showers and thunderstorms. Strong wind gusts near or in excess of 90 km/h will be possible with this band of showers and storms. Given these strong winds, power outages would likely occur in some areas. Environment Canada will continue to monitor this situation closely and may issue watches or warnings as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly around 80 km/h, except locally 100 km/h in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Remarks: local enhancement in southeasterly flow typically occurs in the vicinity of Cape St. George and Port au Port Bay. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain this evening followed by snow Friday. Rain, heavy at times, will begin this evening. Rainfall amounts in the 15 to 25 mm range are possible by the time the rain changes to snow on Friday. There is also the risk of a thunderstorm early Friday. Snowfall amounts are not expected to be more than a few centimetres at this point however a few locations such as Elliot Lake and Temiskaming Shores may receive up to 5 centimetres. On Friday morning a cold front will sweep from west to east with a fairly dramatic temperature drop through the afternoon. This may result in icy conditions on untreated surfaces. Gusty winds near 60 kilometres per hour may result in isolated power outages on Friday. If visibility is reduced while driving, turn on your lights and maintain a safe following distance. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Snow will begin early Friday morning and end Friday night. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T17:43:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-20T01:44:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0241066431.2020
Area: Manic-5 area, Manic-3 area, Chutes-des-Passes - Pipmuacan Reservoir area, Labrieville area, Chevery, Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow, heavy at times, tonight into Friday. Total snowfall amounts up to 20 cm are expected over regions near Fire River, Peterbell, and Elsas by the time the snow tapers off on Friday. Precipitation may be briefly mixed with rain or ice pellets this evening in areas closer to the town of Chapleau. Snowfall amounts up to 15 cm are possible by midday Friday. Northerly winds gusting to 50 km/h will develop early Friday morning causing blowing and drifting snow on Friday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T18:02:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-20T02:03:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4053292854.2020
Area: Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. 15 to 20 centimetres of snow and blowing snow are expected Friday. The snow will begin Thursday night and end Friday evening. Strong winds will develop at midday Friday and give zero visibilities in blowing snow. In addition, temperatures will drop sharply Friday because of a cold front crossing the region. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T17:44:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-20T01:45:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0738015335.2020
Area: Joutel - Matagami area, Miquelon - Desmaraisville area, Chibougamau
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, heavy at times into tonight. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected by the time the snow comes to an end Friday morning. Poor travel is expected. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall tonight into Friday. Snow may briefly mix with rain this evening and then become all snow by late evening. Snow will continue into Friday and then taper off Friday afternoon. Northerly winds gusting to 50 km/h will develop early Friday causing some blowing and drifting snow on Friday. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are expected by Friday afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T17:55:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-20T01:56:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1556182013.2020
Area: Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, at times heavy, and blowing snow tonight into Friday morning. Total snowfall amounts up to 15 cm are expected by the time the snow tapers off Friday afternoon. Northerly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will give blowing and drifting snow at times. Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions tonight into Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T18:08:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-20T02:09:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2394669297.2020
Area: Moosonee
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Upwards of 25 millimetres of rain is expected over higher elevations. The rain, combined with the snowmelt, could accelerate runoff and increase the level of some rivers. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T17:45:13-00:00
